hook.text: A 15-year-old wants chemotherapy but her parents refuse. A 10-year-old wants to refuse it. Who decides?

buildup.text: Children can't legally consent to treatment. Parents typically make medical decisions on their behalf.

discovery.text: The concept of Gillick competence recognizes that some minors can consent if they fully understand the decision.

twist.text: Courts can override parents who refuse lifesaving treatment for religious reasonsâ€”the child's life takes priority.

climax.text: Pediatric ethics balances parental rights, the child's emerging autonomy, and the duty to protect life.

punchline.text: Growing up means gradually owning your own choices.

quiz.question: What is Gillick competence?
options: Recognition that some minors can consent if they fully understand
A test that determines when children become legal adults
A law that prevents children from refusing any treatment
